awd_titl_txt: Advanced numerical methods for multiphysics Magnetohydrodynamics
awd_abstract_narration:
The objective of this project is to develop innovative numerical methods capable of solving energy-related problems in the context of renewable and alternative energies. The numerical techniques developed in this project will help design grid-scale liquid metal batteries capable of storing large quantities of renewable energies. This research will also help improve the performance of large power electric transformers cooled by environment-friendly vegetable-based oils containing ferromagnetic particles. Finally, by facilitating the understanding of magneto-hydrodynamic instabilities in liquid metals, this project will help to ascertain the integrity and the efficiency of the electromagnetic pumps that will be used to extract energy from the next generation of Liquid-Metal Fast-Breeder Reactors and Tokamaks. This project will be done in collaboration with an European team; the project will foster diversity, international exchanges, and multidisciplinarity. The educational component of the project will contribute to increase the competitiveness of the STEM workforce in the US in computational magnetohydrodynamics.

The research program will be organized into four areas: (1) Development of new efficient semi-implicit algorithms to solve partial differential equations with variable material properties (density, electric conductivity, magnetic permeability) using spectral or very high-order methods; (2) Modeling of ferromagnetic fluids and development of new numerical techniques to solve the magneto-static equations in the context of liquid metals and ferromagnetic fluids; (3) Development of level set techniques to account for more than two phases, and development of new high-order level set techniques to guarantee mass conservation and maximum principle; (4) Integration of the mathematical models and numerical techniques developed in (1)-(2)-(3) into a massively parallel open source code to test the proposed methods on realistic applications (liquid metal batteries, thermo-convection of ferromagnetic oil in high-voltage transformers, liquid metal dynamos). This project will involve the Principal Investigator, one post-doctoral collaborator, one graduate student, and European collaborators.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The focus of this research program is to develop advanced numerical
methods for solving multi-physics three-dimensional
magnetohydrodynamics problems.

Intellectual Merit:

This project is both theoretical and applied. The knowledge and
know-how created by the project focus on various energy-related
technologies. Among the phenomenons investigated mathematically and
simulated numerically are the so-called dynamo effect, the Tayler
instability, the thermo-convection of ferromagnetic fluids, the
electro vortex flow mechanism, and the metal pad roll instability.
For instance the dynamo effect is responsible for stellar and
planetary magnetic fields. This effect can also compromise the
integrity and the efficiency of electromagnetic pumps. The Tayler
instability occurs when a strong azimuthal magnetic field amplifies
non-axisymmetric perturbations. This instability is believed to be a
size limiting factor for grid scale liquid metal batteries.  It is
also a possible part of the scenario for the solar dynamo and a source
of helical structures in cosmic jets. The electro-vortex flow
mechanism occurs in liquid metal batteries and can be controlled to
increase the efficiency and longevity of these batteries.  The metal
pad roll phenomenon is an instability that may occur at the interface
of between the top layer and the electrolyte layer in a liquid
battery when the current drawn out of the battery exceeds a certain
limit.


All the phenomenons listed above involve couplings between many
nonlinear equations with heterogeneous properties and free
boundaries. This level of complexity has lead us to develop new
numerical techniques.  In particular, new numerical methods for
solving variable coefficients Partial Differential Equations
semi-implicitly with high-order methods have been developed.  New
models of ferro-fluids and new numerical techniques for solving
thermo-convective problems in ferro-fluids have been investigated.
New techniques for solving free boundary value problems and interface
problems have been proposed.

Broader impact:

This project has developed innovative numerical methods capable of
solving energy-related problems in the context of renewable and
alternative energies. The project has been focused on numerical
methods that are suitable for solving problems involving the motion of
ferromagnetic fluids and current conducting fluids. This research has
applications in the energy industry. For instance, by facilitating the
understanding of the dynamo effect in liquid metals, this project
has helped to ascertain the integrity and the efficiency of the
electromagnetic pumps that will be used to extract energy from the
next generation of Liquid-Metal Fast-Breeder Reactors and
Tokamaks. Finally, this project has also contributed to the effort to
design grid-scale liquid metal batteries capable of storing large
quantities of renewable energies. This research also helped
understanding the heat transfer performance of environment-friendly
vegetable-based transformer oils containing ferromagnetic particles in
large power transformers.  The educational component of the project
has contributed to increase the competitiveness of the STEM workforce
in the US in computational magnetohydrodynamics.  This project has
promoted diversity, international exchanges, and multidisciplinarity.

All the new techniques discovered during this project have been
programmed, tested, verified, validated, and integrated in the open
source high-performance software SFEMaNS. This code is publicly
available. The work accomplished has been reported in the form of
peer-reviewed articles published in scientific journals.


Last Modified: 12/14/2021
Modified by: Jean-Luc Guermond

Images (1 of )
  • Vorticity field in the liquid sodium stirred by two counter rotating impellers. The kinetic energy injected by the impellers is converted in magnetic energy by the dynamo effect.
    Nore, Castanon, Cappanera, Guermond
    Royalty-free (unrestricted use)
    Jean-Luc Guermond
    Direct numerical simulation of the VKS dynamo experiment
  • Direct numerical simulation of the dynamo generated in the VKS experiment. Magnetic field lines of the magnetic field.
    Nore, Castanon, Cappanera, Guermond
    Royalty-free (restricted use - cannot be shared)
    Jean-Luc Guermond
    Dynamo generated in the VKS experiment
  • Left panel shows the temperature field using regular oil as cooling fluid. Right panel shows the temperature field using oil with ferro-particles. Notice that the temperature is lower when ferro-particles are used.
    Zanella, Nore, Bouillaut, Meninger, Guermond
    Royalty-free (unrestricted use)
    Jean-Luc Guermond
    Temperature field in an electric transformer
  • The electrolyte layer pinches when the electro-vortex is too intense. Starting from rest, we show six successive snapshots of the flowintensity and of the interfaces at indicated times. Notice the large deformations of the interface between the top layer and the middle layer (electrolyte).
    Herreman, Nore, Ziebell, Cappanera, Guermond, Weber
    Royalty-free (unrestricted use)
    Jean-Luc Guermond
    Interface dynamics in a liquid Mg-Sb battery
  • Visualization of the interface between the liquid cryolite and the liquid aluminium in the numerical simulations. Eight snapshots over one period in the saturated regime.
    Herreman, Nore, Guermond, Cappanera, Weber, Horstmann
    Royalty-free (unrestricted use)
    Jean-Luc Guermond
    Metal pad roll instability in a liquid bath composed of aluminium and cryolite
  • Snapshots of the molar fraction of Lithium and velocity field induced by the electro-vortex mechanism and solutal buoyancy.
    Herreman, Nore, Cappanera, Guermond
    Jean-Luc Guermond
    Mixing of the Lithium in the bottom layer of a liquid battery
